text: I wanted to show that fire that he had
as a young man it's a very graphic image
in that it's contrasty but it has a lot
of red and yellow in it which is I think
in homage to that fire he had to fight
this fight for freedom my name is Kadir
Nelson I'm an artist and illustrator and
author i created the artwork for the new
yorker cover and i wrote an illustrated
a book called nelson mandela the
challenge of writing a children's book
about Nelson Mandela is to distill this
huge story into something that's
palatable for for young readers I
thought it would be a great idea just to
have his face on the cover to have him
smiling a little bit but seeing that his
eyes are relaxed and that he's at peace
that was an invitation to readers to
open the book you know I started with my
recollection of seeing Nelson Mandela
speak and then I began doing quite a bit
of research looking at photographs of
him from his earliest photographs to
present day this is an image of Nelson
and his comrades after they were
imprisoned there dancing which is a kind
of a tribute to their roots to their
ancestral roots they're calling upon the
ancestors to join them in their struggle
for for freedom and here is sitting
behind bars at the beginning of what
would be a very long sentence
he was a brilliant shining example of
the of a hero I think it's something
that everyone really responds to is
someone who's in a situation and is able
to overcome it or transcend it or stand
on top of it this is an image of Nelson
Mandela shortly after he was elected his
hand is raised in the rebellion against
the government but now it's it's it's
different it's changed its the other
side of it he's got a bright smile and
he's proud that this he fought this
fight and I feel like he was on the
other side of it the winning side of
this fight I actually got to see the
other side of the mountain as dr. Martin
Luther King would say so I choose in
that way to celebrate his life it's I
think it's because it was a life
well-lived
